p: Ross River virus (RRV) is the most common cause of arbovirus-induced disease in Australia, with approximately 5,000 clinical cases reported annually. Infection with RRV is associated with malaise, myalgia, rash, and potentially persistent and debilitating joint symptoms ( 1). People living in the tropical and subtropical regions of northern Queensland, Western Australia, and the Northern Territory are at highest risk of infection ( 1, 2). Disease notifications demonstrate seasonality, based on ideal climatic and environmental conditions that influence vector and reservoir populations, generally during the warmer months (January to April) ( 3).
